Lesson 2: Tika, HÄ“, me te Pono

Truth, Lies & Bias

Year 8 Critical Thinking Unit | 45 minutes

Students learn to identify bias, fake news, and evaluate source credibility

ğŸ“ Materials Needed

  • Chromebooks/tablets for fact-checking activity
  • Printed news headline examples (see below)
  • Google Fact Check Explorer access
  • Student evaluation worksheets
  • Whiteboard for comparison chart

ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ« Teacher Preparation Notes

Key Learning Goals:

  • Recognize different types of bias in sources
  • Use fact-checking tools effectively
  • Compare oral tradition vs. written records as evidence
  • Understand reliability indicators

Vocabulary:

  • Tika (correct, true, right)
  • HÄ“ (wrong, false, mistake)
  • Pono (truth, genuine)
  • PÅ«rÄkau (stories, narratives)
  • Bias (unfair influence or prejudice)
  • Source (origin of information)

Lesson Structure

ğŸ” Starter: News Headline Challenge 10 minutes

Display these headlines about Matariki becoming a public holiday:

Source A - RNZ News:

"Government announces Matariki public holiday to begin in 2022, marking significant recognition of MÄori culture"

Source B - Social Media Post:

"BREAKING: Govt forces ANOTHER holiday on hardworking Kiwis while economy crashes!!! #EnoughIsEnough"

Source C - Stuff.co.nz:

"Matariki public holiday: What you need to know about New Zealand's newest national day"

Quick Discussion Questions:

  1. Which sources seem most reliable? Why?
  2. What language makes some sources seem biased?
  3. How can you tell if a source is trustworthy?

ğŸ’» Main Activity: Fact-Checking Challenge 20 minutes

Using Google Fact Check Explorer

Student Task (Pairs):

  1. Open Google Fact Check Explorer: factcheckexplorer.withgoogle.com
  2. Search for claims about current NZ issues (provided list below)
  3. Evaluate 3 different fact-checks
  4. Complete evaluation worksheet

Suggested Search Topics:

  • "New Zealand climate change"
  • "Auckland house prices"
  • "COVID-19 New Zealand"
  • "All Blacks performance"
  • "MÄori language statistics"

Teacher Support During Activity:

  • Help students navigate the fact-checking tool
  • Encourage critical evaluation of fact-checkers themselves
  • Ask: "Who wrote this fact-check? What are their credentials?"
  • Guide discussion about multiple perspectives

ğŸ“š Cultural Connection: Oral vs. Written Evidence 10 minutes

Te Ao MÄori Perspective on Evidence

Discussion Starter:

"Traditional MÄori knowledge was passed down through pÅ«rÄkau (oral narratives) for centuries. How is this different from written records? Which is more reliable?"

Comparison Activity: Create class comparison chart

Oral Tradition (PÅ«rÄkau) Written Records
Strengths:
  • Preserved for thousands of years
  • Contains cultural wisdom
  • Flexible, adaptable to context
  • Personal connection to storyteller
 Strengths:
  • Exact preservation of words
  • Can be verified by multiple people
  • Date and author clearly recorded
  • Less likely to change over time
Limitations:
  • Can change with each telling
  • Hard to verify exact details
  • May be lost if not passed on
 Limitations:
  • Author's bias affects content
  • May lack cultural context
  • Can be deliberately falsified

Key Question: "How can we use both types of evidence to get a more complete picture of truth?"

ğŸ“Š Wrap-up: Source Reliability Checklist 5 minutes

Class Creation of "Reliability Indicators":

  • âœ… Author credentials clearly listed
  • âœ… Publication date recent and relevant
  • âœ… Multiple sources cited
  • âœ… Language is neutral, not emotional
  • âœ… Different viewpoints acknowledged
  • âœ… Evidence provided for claims
  • âŒ Clickbait headlines
  • âŒ No author listed
  • âŒ Extreme emotional language
  • âŒ No sources provided

ğŸ“Š Assessment: Source Evaluation

Students evaluate one news article using the reliability checklist

Assessment Criteria:

  • Excellent (4): Identifies bias, uses evidence, applies checklist effectively
  • Good (3): Recognizes most bias, some supporting evidence
  • Developing (2): Basic recognition of bias, minimal evidence
  • Beginning (1): Little understanding of source evaluation

ğŸ“„ STUDENT WORKSHEET - FACT-CHECKING INVESTIGATION

Vocabulary Check

  • Tika = ________________
  • HÄ“ = ________________
  • Pono = ________________
  • PÅ«rÄkau = ________________

ğŸ  Homework/Extension

  • Research Task: Find one example of misinformation about MÄori culture and fact-check it
  • Family Connection: Interview whÄnau about how they evaluate news sources
  • Digital Citizenship: Create a social media post teaching others about fact-checking

Lesson 3: Logical Fallacies - Students will learn to spot common errors in reasoning like ad hominem attacks and false causes, using examples from NZ political speeches and advertisements.
